choices.text: Ability to cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.text: Following statement describes the major difference between first and second generation antihistamines medicines. Which amongst the following major properties first generation antihistamines poses as compared to second generation?
questions.solution:
Summary of differences between 1st and 2nd generation H1 Blockers



Option A: Second Generation drugs are More selective to H1 Receptors.

Option C: Second Generation drugs are More effective in treating allergies.

Option D: Second Generation drugs are More potent in blocking H1 Receptors.

Key Takeaway:

First generation antihistamines can cross the blood-brain barrier and cause sedation, as compared to second generation ones which do not have that property.

questions.text: A 60 year old truck driver comes into the pulmonology department complaining that he is sneezing constantly and has burning and watery eyes. He indicates that he seems to have a month or so of these symptoms every spring. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Fexofenadine is a potent histamine H1-receptor antagonist; its poor central nervous system (CNS) penetration reduces sedative effects.

Fexofenadine

It is the active metabolite of terfenadine.

Penetrates blood-brain barrier poorly; produces minimal sedation or

impairment of psychomotor performance. It is free of atropinic side effects.

Fexofenadine has a low propensity to block delayed rectifier K+ channels, and does not prolong QTc interval.

It is largely free of arrhythmogenic potential. However, It is not entirely safe in patients with long QT, bradycardia or hypokalemia.

Option A: Dimenhydrinate affords protection from motion sickness for 4-6 hours, but produces sedation and dryness of mouth. Driving is not advisable after taking these anti-motion sickness drugs

Option B: Scopolamine is the most effective drug for motion sickness.

However, it has a brief duration of action; produces sedation, dry mouth and other anticholinergic side effects.

Option D: Cetirizine is a second generation antihistamine, but it still has some sedating effects.

Key Takeaway

Fexofenadine penetrates blood-brain barrier poorly; produces minimal sedation or impairment of psychomotor performance

questions.text: A 45 year old woman is using a skin patch medication to prevent motion sickness while on a cruise ship. Which of the following adverse effects may result from taking this drug?
questions.solution:
The woman is most likely taking scopolamine, a muscarinic receptor antagonist that may cause dry mouth.

The atropinic natural alkaloids are found in plants of the solanaceae family. The levo-isomers are much more active than the dextro isomers.

Atropine is racemic while scopolamine is l-hyoscine.

Comparative features of atropine and hyoscine



Option A: Anticholinergic Compound can Cause Constipation not Flatulence.

Option B: Anticholinergic May worsen Heartburn in GERD Patients. But with Scopolamine with weak Anticholinergic effect it's not seen.

Option C: Anticholinergic compound can cause Drowsiness & Sedation but not Headache.

Key Takeaway

Scopolamine is the most effective drug for motion sickness. However, it has a brief duration of action; produces sedation, dry mouth and other anticholinergic side effects

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has been suffering from cyclical migraines for many years. She now presents to her physician asking for a medication designated specifically for migraines, not just a general pain reliever. Her physician decided to prescribe sumatriptan as a trial medication. By which of the following mechanisms sumatriptan would bring the relief for migraine?
questions.solution:
Serotonin Receptors Summary

Drug of choices (DOC) for Migraine

Option A: Buspirone Acts via 5HT1a Agonist.

Option C: SSRIs Act via Blocking Reuptake of Serotonin.

Option D: Atypical Antipsychotics act via 5HT2a Antagonist.

Key Takeaway

Sumatriptan is the drug of choice for aborting acute migraine. It acts as a selective agonist at 5 HT1B/1D receptors. It also suppresses the vomiting of migraine

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to his physician complaining of dry mouth,constipation and difficulty in urination. He also noticed an increase in appetite. The man had started therapy with cyproheptadine 2 weeks earlier to treat cold induced urticaria. Drug-induced blockade of which of the following pairs of receptors most likely mediated the patient's complaining symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Cyproheptadine

It primarily blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has additional

  • H1 antihistamine
  • Anticholinergic
  • Sedative properties

It increases appetite and has been used in children as well as in poor eaters to promote weight gain.

The blockade of M3 receptors explains the dry mouth, constipation, and dysuria, while the increase in appetite was likely due to blockade of 5- HT2 receptors in the hypothalamus.

The anti 5-HT activity of cyproheptadine has been utilized in controlling intestinal manifestations of carcinoid and postgastrectomy dumping syndromes, as well as in antagonizing priapism/orgasmic delay caused by 5-HT uptake inhibitors like fluoxetine and trazodone.

Side effects

  • Drowsiness
  • Dry mouth
  • Confusion
  • Ataxia
  • Weight gain

Option A: Cyproheptadine doesn't act via Dopaminergic & Adrenergic Receptors.

Option B: Cyproheptadine doesn't act via H2 Receptors Blockade. (Vs H1 Blockade)

Option C: Cyproheptadine doesn't act via GABAergic Receptors.

Key Takeaway

Cyproheptadine primarily blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has additional H1 antihistamine, Anticholinergic and Sedative properties.

questions.text: A 45 year old surgeon has developed symmetric early morning stiffness in her hands. She also had a previous history of peptic ulceration. Her physician has prescribed a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug to relieve these symptoms at the same time avoiding gastrointestinal side effects. Which oneof the following drugs is most appropriate for her?
questions.solution:
Celecoxib

The COX-2 selectivity of celecoxib is modest (about 10 times). It exerts antiinflammatory, analgesic and antipyretic actions with low ulcerogenic potential.

Comparative trials in rheumatoid arthritis have found it to be as effective as naproxen or diclofenac, without affecting COX-1 activity in gastroduodenal mucosa.

Side effects

  • Abdominal pain,
  • Dyspepsia
  • Mild diarrhoea
  • Rashes
  • Edema

Features of Nonselective COX inhibitors and selective COX-2 inhibitors

Option A: Aspirin, as well as salicylic acid released from it irritate gastric mucosa, cause epigastric distress, nausea and vomiting

Option C: Gastric discomfort, nausea and vomiting, though less than aspirin or indomethacin, are still the most common side effects

Option D: Indomethacin inhibits PLA2 and possesses immunosuppressive properties apart from its COX inhibitory action. It causes more GI upset than other NSAIDs. It is implicated in causing headache (analgesic causing pain).

Key Takeaway

Selective COX-2 Inhibitors have the advantage of very little GI toxicity. However renal toxicity is similar and chances of thrombosis (acute MI and stroke) are increased on prolonged use.

questions.text: A newborn was brought to paediatric NICU with cyanosis and lethargy, later diagnosed as having a congenital abnormality that resulted in transposition of her great arteries. While preparing the infant for surgery, the medical team needed to keep the ductus arteriosus open. Which of the following medicines should be used for the purpose of keeping ductus arteriosus patent whilesurgery?
questions.solution:
PGE1 (Alprostadil) is used To maintain patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects, till corrective surgery is undertaken

PGE1 is continuously produced locally in the ductus arteriosus by COX-2 during foetal life and keeps it patent. At birth its synthesis stops and closure occurs.

Aspirin and indomethacin induce closure when it fails to occur spontaneously.

Prostaglandins and their Systemic effects:

Option A: Cortisol Doesn't affect Patency of Ductus Arteriosus.

Option B: Indomethacin Closes Ductus Arteriosus so Used in PDA.

Option C: ketorolac closes ductus Arteriosus so used in PDA.

Key Takeaway:

PGE1 (Alprostadil) is used To maintain patency of ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic woman with history of having suicidal tendency, brought to the emergency department by her husband, was disoriented and complained of headache, vertigo, and tinnitus. Vital signs were temperature 103.8°F, pulse 108 bpm, respirations 6/min, Blood pressure 90/60 mmhg. Relevant laboratory data on admission were arterial blood pH 7.25, bicarbonate 18 mEq/L. Arterial blood gases were PaCO2 48 mm Hg, PaO2 75 mm Hg. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's poisoning?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, the marked hyperthermia, and the respiratory depression suggest severe poisoning by salicylates.

This is supported by the lab results indicating mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis (low pH, increased PaCO2, and decreased plasma bicarbonate content). This acid-base disturbance is typical of a high salicylate content in blood.

Acute salicylate poisoning:

Fatal dose in adults is estimated to be 15-30 g, but is considerably

lower in children.

Manifestations are:

  • Vomiting,
  • Dehydration
  • Electrolyte imbalance
  • Acidotic breathing
  • Hyper/hypoglycemia
  • Petechial haemorrhages
  • Restlessness, Delirium, Hallucinations
  • Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, coma
  • Death due to respiratory failure + cardiovascular

Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Most important is external cooling and i.v. fluid with Na+, K+, HCO3¯ and glucose according to need.

Relationship between the dosage of aspirin and the pharmacologic and toxic effects of the drug.

Aspirin side effects:

  • Mnemonic : [ASPIRIN]

Allergic like reactions (urticaria) Susceptibility to bleeding Peptic ulcer

Idiosyncratic reactions

Reye's syndrome

RInging in ears (Tinnitus)

Nephropathy

Option A: Acute alcohol poisoning can cause violent behavior, but hypothermia and hypoglycemia are typical signs of alcohol poisoning, and tinnitus is usually absent.

Option B & C: Poisoning by non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs other than salicylates does not usually cause profound impairment of the acid-base balance.

Key Takeaway:

Acute salicylate poisoning occurs in adults when a fatal dose of aspirin is taken which is estimated to be 15-30 g, characterised by marked hyperthermia, and respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 59 year old obese woman presented to the emergency department because of severe colicky pain in the right lumbar region. The patient had a long history of osteoarthritis and experienced frequent episodes of strong arthritic pain for which she had been taking several different pain killers daily for the past year. Concomitant medications included atorvastatin, ezetimibe and hydrochlorothiazide. A renal biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of papillary necrosis and tubulointerstitial inflammation of the kidney. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The culprit drug was most likely an NSAID such as diclofenac.

Chronic use (6 to 8 months or more) of antipyretic analgesics can cause a nephropathy that is characterized by renal papillary necrosis (the primary lesion) and chronic interstitial nephritis.

Common adverse effects of NSAIDs

Option A: Tramadol is associated with nausea and dizziness, sleepiness, dry mouth, sweating and lowering of seizure threshold.

Option C: Adverse Effects of thiazide diuretics include Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyponatremia, alkalosis, hyperglycemia (C/I in DM), hyperuricemia (C/I in gout) and dyslipidemia.

Option D: Atorvastatin is associated with Gastrointestinal complaints and headache, Rashes and sleep disturbances. Muscle aches are the commonest (10%) side effect. Rise in serum transaminase can occur, but liver damage is infrequent. Monitoring of liver function is recommended.

Key Takeaway

Analgesic nephropathy occurs after years of heavy ingestion of analgesics. Regular use of combinations of NSAIDs and chronic/repeated urinary tract infections increase the risk of analgesic nephropathy.

Pathological lesions are papillary necrosis, tubular atrophy followed by renal fibrosis.

questions.text: A 60 year old female with a history of having multiple renal stones was admitted to the surgical department for pyelolithotomy. She also had a previous history of renal impairment. Which of the following is the analgesic of choice in this patient for Post operative phase?
questions.solution:
Paracetamol is one of the most commonly used 'over-the-counter' analgesic but is relatively ineffective when inflammation is prominent.

It is one of the best drugs to be used as antipyretic for fever due to any cause, especially in children (no risk of Reye's syndrome). Metabolism occurs mainly by conjugation with glucuronic acid and sulfate:

conjugates are excreted rapidly in urine.

Paracetamol is equally efficacious to aspirin for noninflammatory conditions.

  • Advantages of Paracetamol over Aspirin
    • Much safer in terms of gastric irritation, ulceration and bleeding
    • Does not prolong bleeding time
    • Hypersensitivity reactions are rare; no metabolic effects of acid- base disturbances.
    • Paracetamol can be used in all age groups (infants to elderly), pregnant/lactating women
    • No significant drug

Option A, B & C:

All of them can be associated with analgesic nephropathy. Analgesic nephropathy occurs after years of heavy ingestion of analgesics.

Regular use of combinations of NSAIDs and chronic/repeated urinary tract infections increase the risk of analgesic nephropathy. Pathological lesions are papillary necrosis, tubular atrophy followed by renal fibrosis.

Key Takeaway

Paracetamol can be used in all age groups (infants to elderly), pregnant/lactating women, in presence of other disease states and in patients in whom aspirin is contraindicated.

choices.text: Binding to necrotic ulcer tissue, acting as a barrier for acid and pepsin
Blockade of Muscarinic M3 receptors on gastric parietal cells
Blockade of Gastrin receptors on gastric parietal cells
Stimulation of bicarbonate and mucus secretion by superficial epithelial cells

questions.text: A 67 year old woman was brought to the medicine department with complaints of persistent heartburn. She had been taking ibuprofen for osteoarthritis of the right hip for the past 2 months. Her physician prescribed another drug, to be taken together with ibuprofen, to prevent peptic ulcer formation. Which of the following actions most likely contributed to the preventive effect of the prescribed drug?
questions.solution:
The patient's history and symptoms suggest that she was at risk of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID)-induced ulcer.

Misoprostol, a synthetic analogue of prostaglandin E1, is the drug most often prescribed, as it is able to prevent (but not to treat) NSAID- induced ulcers.

This preventive effect is most likely due to the following mechanisms:

  • At low doses, misoprostol activates prostaglandin receptors on superficial epithelial cells of the stomach, increasing bicarbonate and mucus secretion (the so-called cytoprotective effect).
  • At higher doses, it activates prostaglandin receptors on parietal cells of the stomach, decreasing gastric acid secretion (most likely the main mechanism).

Option A: These are the mechanisms of action of sucralfate or of bismuth compounds. These drugs are much less effective than misoprostol when the ulcer is secondary to chronic ingestion of NSAIDs.

Option B: This is the mechanism of action of antimuscarinic drugs. These drugs are no longer used as antiulcer agents.

Option C: This is the mechanism of action of Netazepide. Its use is limited in Treating GERD.

Key Takeaway

Misoprostol, a synthetic analogue of prostaglandin E1, is the drug most often prescribed, as it is able to prevent (but not to treat) NSAID-induced ulcers.

questions.text: A 78 year old man complained to his physician of dull, continuous bone pain that had been increasing over the past few days. The patient had been suffering from prostatic carcinoma for 2 years. Patient had a history of glucose- 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and an allergic reaction tonaproxen. Which of the following would be the most appropriate analgesic drug for this patient considering his past history?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and the history of the patient suggest the pain was caused by bone metastases, which are the most frequent metastases in prostatic carcinoma.

Osseous metastases induce an inflammatory reaction with the production of prostaglandins that may cause osteolysis and sensitize free nerve endings, augmenting pain perception.

Piroxicam is a long-acting, nonselective, competitive inhibitor of cyclooxygenase with following properties:

  • Inhibits polymorphonuclear cell migration and decreases oxygen radical production.
  • Lowers prostaglandins concentration in synovial fluid and inhibits platelet aggregation
  • In addition, it decreases the production of free radicals and IgM rheumatoid factor. Leukocyte chemotaxis is inhibited.

Option A: Aspirin is contraindicated because of his glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency (salicylates can cause hemolytic anemia in patients with this deficiency).

Option B: Acetaminophen is a very weak inhibitor of cyclooxygenase in the presence of high concentrations of peroxide that are found in inflammatory lesions.

Option D: All propionic acid derivatives are contraindicated because of the serious allergic reaction to naproxen.

Key Takeaway:

Piroxicam It is a long-acting potent NSAID with antiinflammatory

potency similar to indomethacin and good analgesic-antipyretic action. In addition, it decreases the production of free radicals and IgM rheumatoid factor. Leukocyte chemotaxis is inhibited. Thus, it can inhibit inflammation in diverse ways.

questions.text: A 48 year old woman was brought to the emergency department with chief complaints of serious breathing difficulty. Two hours earlier, she had taken a drug for a headache. The patient had been suffering from sinusitis and nasal polyps for 6 months. Physical examination showed severe bronchospasm. Which of the following drug most likely caused the patient's signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's history and symptoms suggest that the culprit drug was aspirin.

She was affected by aspirin hypersensitivity, a syndrome that can occur in middle-aged patients with asthma, chronic urticaria, or nasal polyps, as in this case.

The reaction does not appear to be immunologic in nature, but instead seems to be a pseudoallergic reaction.

The mechanism is likely related to the formation of increased amounts of leukotrienes and other products of the lipoxygenase pathway due to inhibition of the cyclooxygenase pathway. Patients with this syndrome experience a high degree of cross-sensitivity to other NSAIDs.

  • Contraindications of Aspirin:
  • Mnemonic : [BARS]

Bleeding

Asthma

Renal disease (nephropathy)

Stomach (Peptic ulcer)

  • Aspirin side effects:
  • Mnemonic : [ASPIRIN]

Allergic like reactions (urticaria)

Susceptibility to bleeding

Peptic ulcer

Idiosyncratic reactions

Reye's syndrome

RInging in ears (Tinnitus)

Nephropathy

Other Options:

She was affected by aspirin hypersensitivity, a syndrome that can occur in middle-aged patients with asthma, chronic urticaria, or nasal polyps, as in this case. So Options A, B & D Are Ruled out.

Key Takeaway:

Aspirin is associated with Hypersensitivity and idiosyncrasy reactions including rashes, fixed drug eruption, urticaria, rhinorrhoea, angioedema, asthma and anaphylactoid reaction.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man recently diagnosed with mild rheumatoid arthritis complained to his physician of joint pain despite ongoing therapy with ibuprofen. The man was a heavy smoker and had a history of chronic bronchitis with frequent acute exacerbations usually treated with antibiotics. The physician decided to add a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) to the treatment. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for the patient at this time?
questions.solution:
The therapy of mild rheumatoid arthritis usually includes nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that can control symptoms of pain and swelling.

Hydroxychloroquine seems to be the least toxic among DMARDs and is usually the initial choice. Moreover, in this patient, immunosuppressant drugs are relatively contraindicated because of his frequent respiratory tract infections.

Hydroxychloroquine/Chloroquine:

These are antimalarial drugs found to induce remission in upto 50% patients of rheumatoid arthritis, but take 3-6 months. Their advantage is relatively low toxicity, but efficacy is also low; bony erosions are not prevented.

Their proposed mechanism of actions are:

  • Reduce monocyte IL-I, consequently inhibiting B lymphocytes
  • Interfering with Antigen processing
  • Lysosomal stabilization and free radical scavenging

Conventional DMARDs

  • Mnemonic [Cute and PAGLI Maria Shrarapova]

Option A: It is a prodrug (converted in the body to an active metabolite) that inhibits the enzyme dihydro orotate dehydrogenase. It is faster acting (action is manifested in 4 weeks as compared to 3 months with other DMARDs) alternative to methotrexate.

Option C: It is a monoclonal antibody that depletes B-cells and is used for RA in combination with methotrexate.

Option D: TNF-α plays a major role in the joint destruction in patients with RA. Five drugs etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab, golimumab and certolizumab act as DMARDs by blocking the action of TNF-α.

Key Takeaway :

Hydroxychloroquine is the least toxic among DMARDs and is usually the initial choice of drug in mild cases of rheumatoid arthritis

choices.text: The patient is resistant to the allopurinol and should be placed on another medication.
The patient likely has an arthritis syndrome produced by allopurinol and should have an antinuclear antibody (ANA) drawn.
The patient likely developed acute gout as a result of mobilization of the urate from joints and tissues.
This likely represents a drug-drug interaction, and so the allopurinol should be discontinued.

questions.text: A 44 year old man is suffering from recurrent gouty arthritis. On investigations his serum uric acid level is elevated. His physician has prescribed allopurinol. Within 1 week of taking allopurinol, he suddenly develops a painful episode of acute gout. Which of the following is the best explanation fordevelopment of acute gout attack even if starting allopurinol?
questions.solution:
The patient likely developed an acute episode of gout as a result of the mobilization of urate from joints and tissues, a phenomenon commonly seen with initiation of allopurinol.

Allopurinol as well as uricosurics should not be started during acute attack of gout.

During the initial 1-2 months of treatment with these drugs, attacks of acute gout are more common-probably due to fluctuating plasma

urate levels favouring intermittent solubilisation and recrystallization in joints.

This period should be covered by NSAIDs or colchicine.

Pharmacotherapy of Gout:


Flowchart Showing synthesis and inhibition of uric acid synthesis:

Other Options:

Other Options are Incorrect as Allopurinol causes gout attacks probably due to fluctuating plasma urate levels favouring intermittent solubilisation and recrystallization in joints.

Key Takeaway:

Allopurinol as well as uricosurics should not be started during acute attack of gout.

During the initial 1-2 months of treatment with these drugs, attacks of acute gout are more common probably due to fluctuating plasmaurate levels favouring intermittent solubilisation and recrystallization in joints

questions.text: A 61 year old male patient has 5-6 painful gouty attacks every year despite being treated with febuxostat. He is highly allergic to probenecid. Which of the following would be the best course of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Pegloticase:

It is recombinant uricase, an enzyme which oxidizes uric acid to highly soluble allantoin, that is easily excreted by the kidney. It is indicated only in rare cases of refractory symptomatic gout.

Pegloticase is immunogenic and carries high risk of infusion reactions including anaphylaxis. It should be administered only by professionals in a setting where facilities for managing anaphylaxis are available.

Due to formation of antibodies, the response is gradually lost in many patients.

Option A: NSAIDs like indomethacin are drugs of choice due to better tolerability. Aspirin is not used as it may cause hyperuricemia.

Option C: Probenecid, sulfinpyrazone acts as competitive inhibitors of reabsorption of uric acid in proximal tubules.

Option D: Allopurinol (hypoxanthine analog) and febuxostat (a non-purine drug) decrease the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. These are indicated as drug of choice for chronic gout in the inter- critical period (between two acute attacks).

Key Takeaway:

Pegloticase and rasburicase are administered by I.V. route and are indicated only in patients with chronic gout refractory to other treatments.

questions.text: A 55 year old woman is being treated for Rheumatoid arthritis. Her disease has become much worse, and a new medication is added by her physician. After 6 months, she notes night sweats, weight loss, chronic cough, evening rise in fever and a chest radiograph that indicates a cavitary lesion. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed for Rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The anti-TNF-α immunoglobulin agents are usually well tolerated and modify the disease process of Rheumatoid arthritis; however, they tend to predispose patients to infections, particularly tuberculosis.

The patient in the question has a typical clinical presentation of tuberculosis. Diagnosis would be confirmed by sputum culture and acid fast smear, and therapy started with multiple anti-tuberculosis agents.

Anti-TNF- α drugs for Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Mnemonic [GLACIER]

GoLimumab

Adalimumab

Certolizumab

lnfliximab

EtaneRcept

Common features:

  • All are injectable
  • Increase Risk of infections
  • Contra-indicated in Tuberculosis and Hepatitis B

Uses:Apart from Rheumatoid arthritis, these drugs can be used for Crohn's disease as well as Psoriasis.

Biological DMARDs

Option A: Gold salts are highly efficacious DMARDs but are rarely used now due to severe toxic reactions. Gold salts can be used orally (auranofin) as well as intramuscularly (aurothiomalate). Dermatitis is the most common adverse effect seen with gold salts.

Option C: Methotrexate is first choice DMARD and is used at much lower doses with risk of side effects like Gastric irritation and stomatitis (most common), Pancytopenia, Hepatotoxicity with fibrosis and cirrhosis,Interstitial pneumonitis (Hypersensitivity reaction) & Teratogenicity.

Option D: The antiinflammatory activity is stronger and it is particularly potent in inhibiting leukocyte migration-may be more valuable in acute gout. Gastric bleeding is more common.

Key Takeaway:

Infliximab is usually well tolerated and modifies the disease process of Rheumatoid arthritis; however, they tend to predispose patients to infections, particularly tuberculosis.

questions.text: A physician has been treating a 42 year old woman with mild rheumatoid arthritis for 4 years with ibuprofen. She has returned to the physician and complains that the pain in her wrists is worse and 800 mg/day of ibuprofen does not give adequate relief. Her physician has now started an etanercept for her rheumatoid arthritis. For which of the following serious adverse effectsmust the patient be cautioned for?
questions.solution:
Infections are a common and potentially serious adverse effect of the DMARDs.

Etanercept:

It is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.

Side effects:

  • Injection site Pain, redness, itching and swelling
  • Chest infections

Anti-TNF- α drugs for Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Mnemonic [GLACIER]

GoLimumab

Adalimumab

Certolizumab

lnfliximab

EtaneRcept

Common features:

  • All are injectable
  • Increase Risk of
  • Contra-indicated in Tuberculosis and Hepatitis B

Option A: NSAIDs cause Gastrointestinal bleeding.

Option B: The DMARDs do not cause anemia.

Option D: The DMARDs Don't cause hallucinations.

Key Takeaway:

Infections are a common and potentially serious adverse effect of the DMARDs.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient receiving cancer chemotherapy was brought to the medicine department with complaints of anorexia, abdominal distension with flank pain, oliguria, fatigue and muscle cramps. He was later diagnosed with tumor lysis syndrome. Which of the following is the fastest uric acid lowering therapy in tumor lysis syndrome to prevent renal damage?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase that has been shown to lower urate levels more effectively than allopurinol.

Indications:

  • Management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in pediatric and adult patients with leukemia & lymphoma
  • Solid tumor malignancies who are receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis and significant hyperuricemia.

Side effects:

  • Hemolysis in G6PD-deficient patients,
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Acute renal failure
  • Anaphylaxis

Other includes vomiting, fever, nausea, headache, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, and mucositis.

Option A: Allopurinol (hypoxanthine analog) decreases the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. These are indicated as drug of choice for chronic gout in the inter-critical period (between two acute attacks).

Option B: febuxostat (a non-purine drug) decreases the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. These are indicated as drug of choice for chronic gout in the inter-critical period (between two acute attacks).

Option D: Furosemide causes hyperuricemia and should be avoided in patients with gout.

Key Takeaway:

Rasburicase is administered by I.V. route and are indicated only in patients with chronic gout refractory to other treatments & to prevent hyperuricemia during tumor lysis syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complained to his physician of blurred vision, night blindness, light flashes, and photophobia. The man was diagnosed with mild rheumatoid arthritis 6 months ago and was taking a combination therapy that included a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD). Ophthalmoscopy disclosed a macular area of hyperpigmentation surrounded by a zone of hypopigmentation on the left retina (as shown in the figure below). Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Effects of Hydroxychloroquine in retina:

In the retinal pigment epithelium, accumulation of chloroquine causes a toxic retinal lesion known as a 'bull's-eye' maculopathy, which is associated with a decrease in visual acuity.

To reduce the risk of retinal toxicity from chloroquine and related substances (e.g., hydroxychloroquine), patients receiving chronic therapy should receive periodic eye exams.

Ocular adverse-effects of drugs

Option A: Methotrexate is first choice DMARD and is used at much lower doses with risk of side effects like Gastric irritation and stomatitis (most common), Pancytopenia, Hepatotoxicity with fibrosis and cirrhosis,Interstitial pneumonitis (Hypersensitivity reaction) & Teratogenicity.

Option C: It is a prodrug (converted in the body to an active metabolite) that inhibits the enzyme dihydro orotate dehydrogenase. It is faster acting (action is manifested in 4 weeks as compared to 3 months with other DMARDs) alternative to methotrexate. Liver and kidney damage are major toxicities.

Option D: Sulfasalazine causes Neutropenia/thrombocytopenia in about 5-10% patients; regular blood count monitoring is needed.

Key Takeaway:

  • In the retinal pigment epithelium, accumulation of chloroquine causes a toxic retinal lesion known as a 'bull's-eye' maculopathy, which is associated with a decrease in visual acuity.
  • Corneal deposits may also occur and affect vision, but are reversible on

questions.text: A 43-year-old man suffering from rheumatoid arthritis complained to his physician that his joint pain had increased recently despite current naproxen and hydroxychloroquine therapy. The patient was otherwise healthy, and his past medical history was unremarkable. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to add to the patient's therapy at this time?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is currently a first-line treatment for most patients with rheumatoid arthritis because

  • High rate of response,
  • Relatively rapid onset of action (1 to 2 months) and
  • Long sustained

This dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor has prominent immunosuppressant and antiinflammatory property.

Beneficial effects in Rheumatoid arthritis are probably related to Inhibition of cytokine production, chemotaxis and cell-mediated immune reaction.Proliferation of immune-inflammatory cells is inhibited.

Mtx is the DMARD of first choice and the standard treatment for most patients, including cases of juvenile Rheumatoid arthritis.

Side effects:

  • Dose dependent progressive liver damage leading to cirrhosis
  • Incidence of chest infections has increased

Mtx is contraindicated in pregnancy, breast-feeding, liver disease, active infection, leukopenia and peptic ulcer.

Option A: The patient was already receiving a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, so the addition of another drug of the same class would be of little value.

Option B: The patient was already receiving a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, so the addition of another drug of the same class would be of little value.

Option D: Fentanyl is a powerful opioid drug. Opioid analgesics are used in rheumatoid arthritis only exceptionally, on an as-needed basis, when the pain is excruciating.

Key Takeaway:

Methotrexate is currently a first-line treatment for most patients with rheumatoid arthritis because of its beneficial profile especially in mild patients with RA.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of migraine reports to her physician that the last time she used her medicine to stop an acute attack, she felt numbness and tingling in her extremities and blanching and cyanosis of her Fingers as shown in the figure below. Which one of the following medications most likely did she take?
questions.solution:
Dihydroergotamine (DHE) is an ergot alkaloid, and these agents are known to cause vasoconstriction and paresthesia in the extremities, especially at high doses.

Ergot Alkaloids:

  • These are derived from a fungus called Claviceps purpurea. Important compounds are :
  • Ergotamine,
  • Ergometrine (ergonovine),
  • Ergotoxine,
  • Bromocriptine,
  • Dihydroergotamine
  • Methysergide

These drugs possess partial agonistic and antagonistic effects at 5HT, α and dopaminergic receptors. Ergotamine and dihydroergotamine are used for the treatment of acute migraine.

Ergot derivatives can cause dry gangrene of the hand and feet as well as coronary vasospasm.These are contraindicated in patients with ischemic heart disease (due to their propensity to cause coronary vasospasm).

Option A: Methysergide, is also an ergot but is not used for acute treatment of migraine attacks.

Option B: Sumatriptan, is a triptan also used for acute attacks and can cause vasoconstriction, but not as commonly as observed with DHE.

Option D: Tramadol, is a dual-action opioid agent.

Key Takeaway:

Dihydroergotamine (DHE) is an ergot alkaloid, and these agents are known to cause vasoconstriction and paresthesia in the extremities.

questions.text: A 45 year old female came to a neurologist with a history of having recurrent migraine attacks. Her neurologist has suggested adding a drug for migraine prophylaxis. Which of the following agents has not shown effectiveness in the prophylactic treatment of migraine headache?
questions.solution:
The triptan agents are effective only in the acute treatment of a migraine headache.

They are agonists at 5-HT1B/1D receptors in cerebral blood vessels that

produce vasoconstriction, on trigeminal nerve endings inhibiting the release of inflammatory substances, and in the brain stem to prevent activation of trigeminal nerves.

Drugs for Prophylaxis of migraine :


Drug of choices (DOC) for Migraine

Option B, C & D: Valproic acid, Verapamil & Amitriptyline all of them are used as migraine prophylaxis.

Key Takeaway:

Propranolol, Valproic acid, Verapamil & Amitriptyline all of them are used as migraine prophylaxis.

questions.text: A young female presented with a left sided severe throbbing headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia and phonophobia. Which of the following drugs can provide immediate relief to this patient?
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan :

It is the first selective 5-HT1D/1B receptor agonist

Advantages of Triptans over Ergot compounds:

  • Sumatriptan is effective and better tolerated than
  • It tends to suppress nausea and vomiting of migraine
  • The triptans have been found to suppress neurogenic inflammation of cranial vessels.

The antimigraine activity of sumatriptan has been ascribed to 5-HT1D/1B receptor mediated constriction of dilated cranial blood vessels, especially the arterio-venous shunts in the carotid artery, which express 5-HT1D/1B receptors.

The use of sumatriptan (or other triptans) should be restricted to treatment of acute attacks of moderate to severe migraine not responding to analgesics or their combinations.

Drug of choices (DOC) for Migraine

Options A, C & D: All of them are used as drugs for migraine prophylaxis.

Key Takeaway:

Sumatriptan (subcutaneous) is the drug of choice for aborting acute attack of migraine. It acts as a selective agonist at 5 HT1B/1D receptors.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man was brought to the medicine department with complaints of chronic cough, hoarseness of voice and acute weight loss. He had a history of chronic cigarette smoking. On further workup he has a large mass seen on a chest X-ray. The patient reports a 20-25 kg unintentionalweight loss over the last 3 months and a poor appetite. In addition to beginning chemotherapy, the oncologist decides to add which of the following agents to promote his appetite?
questions.solution:
Megestrol acetate is used as

  • Appetite stimulant in patients with AIDS or cancer-associated cachexia
  • Treatment of endometrial cancer and rarely of breast and prostate cancer

Dronabinol is also used in the treatment of AIDS wasting, specifically to increase appetite.

Drugs for Obesity

Drugs promoting appetite

Option A & C: Aprepitant NK 1 Antagonist, used for nausea and vomiting, which he may experience eventually with his chemotherapy.

Option B: Orlistat is a reversible lipase inhibitor used for the management of obesity. It inactivates the enzymes, thus making them unavailable to digest dietary fats.

Option C: ondansetron acts via 5HT3 Antagonist is used for nausea and vomiting, which he may experience eventually with his chemotherapy.

Key Takeaway:

Megestrol acetate is used as Appetite stimulant in patients with AIDS or cancer-associated cachexia.
